description: From Anglo-Norman mathesis, Middle French mathesie, and their source, Late Latin mathesis (“astrology, liberal arts, science”), from Ancient Greek μάθησις (máthēsis, “learning”), from the same base as μανθάνω (manthánō, “I learn”).

entries.meaning: (now rare) Mental calculation or discipline; science, especially mathematical learning. [from 15th c.]
examples: Forget the Boys, forget your loyalties to your Dead, first of all to Rebekah, for she, they, are but distractions, temporal, flesh, ever attempting to drag the Uranian Devotee back down out of his realm of pure Mathesis, of that which abides.

entries.meaning: The science of establishing a systematic order for things. (After Foucault.) [from 1970s]
examples: I’m using 'mathesis' — a universal science of measurement and order  […]
